Enrollment Requirements: Pre-registration - Reserved for History & International Studies students.

Freshmen may not register for this course.
title: WCAS HISTORY 395-0-22 Research Seminar

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This seminar is designed to provide students of history, Asian studies, and international affairs with the opportunity to engage in sustained historical research and writing over the course of an entire quarter. The first two-thirds of the course will be devoted to reading a variety of source materials relating to the subject of imperialism in East, South, and Southeast Asia. The last third of the course will be devoted to the research and writing of a term paper on any topic of your choice relating to the history of colonialism and imperialism in these regions. Students may wish to examine certain genres of primary source material: missionary writings, diplomatic correspondence, or travel literature, for example. Or students might wish to evaluate the secondary source literature on those topics concerning which there has been extended scholarly debate (for example, the Vietnam Wars; the Japanese occupation of Southeast Asia; the American enterprise in the Philippines; some aspect of British imperialism in India, Singapore, or Hong Kong; the Boxer Uprising and War; some aspect of the Cold War in Asia; gender and empire in a particular place; and so on). The purpose of this paper is not to write a major undergraduate study, but to write the kind of polished term paper that is not usually possible during the frenzied schedule of the quarter system. We will define imperialism broadly and you will have great leeway deciding your term paper topic.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Seminar & Individual Sessions with the Professor

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Participation, One Short Paper based upon a book that is central to your research (2 pgs.), & Final Paper (15-20 pgs.)
